content.description: Ascend a wide, flared crack with a tough mantel to start. When exploring the area, we skipped over this crack, but a passerby pointed out that someone had installed a 2 bolt anchor at the top. So I geared up and led it. Most of the spice is down low. There's a tricky mantel to get established in the crack.
content.location: It is in the middle of the wall. You can see bolts from the meadow.

content.description: This ascends a left-angling crack up a slab. It takes some protection in the middle section where the crack forms a V. You can walk around to set up an anchor by slinging a big boulder. Don't sling the detached boulder as it moved when I pulled on it.
content.protection: Medium-sized cams. I used (BD equivalent sizes) a #1, #3, & a #0.75. Sling a big boulder at the top for a toprope anchor.
content.location: Directly across from the campsite, there are a few sets of rocks this goes up the left patch.

content.description:
On a small face, climb up to the roof, and find protection in a crack running out the underside of the roof. Make a nice, sliding V with two cams as they'll be your only protection for pulling the one move wonder of a 5.11 roof. This is easier for taller people.

You could downgrade this to a V3ish boulder if you want, just remember that it's not going to make anyone think you're cool.
content.location:
It is on the left side of the big rocks. You'll know the roof when you see it.

You can walk around and set up an anchor. I slung a tree and put some cams in the vertical crack next to it. Options exist for directions to keep the rope running smoothly.
